column1: La Crosse is a city in the U.S. state of Wisconsin and the county seat of La Crosse County. Positioned alongside the Mississippi River
column2: La Crosse is the largest city on Wisconsin's western border. La Crosse's estimated population in 2019 was 51
column3: 227. The city forms the core of and is the principal city in the La Crosse Metropolitan Area
column4: which includes all of La Crosse County and Houston County

column1: The first Europeans to see the site of La Crosse were French fur traders who traveled the Mississippi River in the late 17th century. There is no written record of any visit to the site until 1805
column2: when Lt. Zebulon Pike mounted an expedition up the Mississippi River for the United States. Pike recorded the location's name as "Prairie La Crosse". The name originated from the game with sticks that resembled a bishop's crozier or la crosse in French
column3: which was played by Native Americans there.The first white settlement at La Crosse occurred in 1841 when Nathan Myrick
column4: a New York native
column5: moved to the village at Prairie du Chien
column6: Wisconsin to work in the fur trade. Myrick was disappointed to find that because many fur traders were already well-entrenched there
column7: there were no openings for him in the trade. As a result
column8: he decided to establish a trading post upriver at the then still unsettled site of Prairie La Crosse. In 1841
column9: he built a temporary trading post on Barron Island (now called Pettibone Park)
column10: which lies just west of La Crosse's present downtown. The following year
column11: Myrick relocated the post to the mainland prairie
column12: partnering with H. J. B. Miller to run the outfit.The spot Myrick chose to build his trading post proved ideal for settlement. It was near the junction of the Black
column15: the post was built at one of the few points along the Wisconsin side of the Mississippi River where a broad plain ideal for development existed between the river's bank and the tall bluffs that line the river valley. Because of these advantages
column16: a small village grew around Myrick's trading post in the 1840s.

column1: A small Mormon community settled at La Crosse in 1844
column2: building several dozen cabins a few miles south of Myrick's post. Although these settlers relocated away from the Midwest after just a year
column3: the land they occupied near La Crosse continues to bear the name Mormon Coulee.On June 23
column5: Father James Lloyd Breck of the Episcopal Church said the first Christian liturgy on top of Grandad Bluff. Today a monument to that event stands atop the bluff
column6: near the parking lot at a scenic overlook.

column1: More permanent development took place closer to Myrick's trading post
column2: where stores
column3: a hotel
column4: and a post office were constructed during the 1840s. Under the direction of Timothy Burns
column6: surveyor William Hood platted the village in 1851. This opened it up for further settlement
column7: which was achieved rapidly as a result of promotion of the city in eastern newspapers. By 1855
column8: La Crosse had grown in population to nearly 2
column10: leading to its incorporation in 1856. The city grew even more rapidly after 1858 with the completion of the La Crosse & Milwaukee Railroad
column11: the second railroad connecting Milwaukee to the Mississippi River.

column1: During the second half of the 19th century
column2: La Crosse grew to become one of the largest cities in Wisconsin. It was a center of the lumber industry
column3: for logs cut in the interior of the state could be rafted down the Black River toward sawmills built in the city. La Crosse also became a center for the brewing industry and other manufacturers that saw advantages in the city's location adjacent to major transportation arteries
column4: such as the Mississippi River and the railroad between Milwaukee and St. Paul
column5: Minnesota. Around the turn of the 20th century
column6: the city also became a center for education
column7: with three colleges and universities established in the city between 1890 and 1912.

column2: Mayors Tim Kabat and John Medinger issued a proclamation apologizing for La Crosse's history as a sundown town that discriminated against African Americans.La Crosse remains the largest city on Wisconsin's western border
column3: and the educational institutions in the city have recently led it toward becoming a regional technology and medical hub.

column1: La Crosse is located on the western border of the midsection of Wisconsin
column2: on a broad alluvial plain along the east side of the Mississippi River. The Black River empties into the Mississippi north of the city
column3: and the La Crosse River flows into the Mississippi just north of the downtown area. Just upriver from its mouth
column4: this river broadens into a marshland that splits the city into two distinct sections

column4: 20.52 square miles (53.15 km2) is land and 2.02 square miles (5.23 km2) is water.Surrounding the relatively flat prairie valley where La Crosse lies are towering 500-foot bluffs
column5: one of the most prominent of which is Grandad Bluff (mentioned in Life on the Mississippi by Mark Twain)
column6: which has an overlook of the three states region. This feature typifies the topography of the Driftless Area in which La Crosse sits. This rugged region is composed of high ridges dissected by narrow valleys called coulees
column7: a French term. As a result
column8: the area around La Crosse is frequently referred to as the "Coulee Region".

column1: La Crosse's location in the United States' upper midwest gives the area a temperate
column2: continental climate. The warmest month of the year is July
column3: when the average high temperature is 84.1 °F (28.9 °C)
column4: with overnight low temperatures averaging 63.2 °F (17.3 °C). January is the coldest month
column6: with the overnight low temperatures around 8.9 °F (−12.8 °C).

column1: The city government employs a weak mayor form of the mayor-council system. The mayor is elected at-large
column2: while the 13 members of the Common Council are elected per aldermanic districts. The mayor is Tim Kabat
column3: a progressive.Both the city and county of La Crosse have voted Democratic in every presidential election since 1988. In the 2016 Presidential Election
column4: Hillary Clinton won by 52% of the City of La Crosse. In the 2012 presidential election
column5: Barack Obama won 65% of the city of La Crosse and 58% of La Crosse County. In 2014
column6: the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel ranked La Crosse as one of Wisconsin's top performing Democratic cities.In the United States Congress
column7: Democrat Ron Kind has represented La Crosse as part of Wisconsin's 3rd congressional district since 1997. The city is almost coterminous with the 95th Wisconsin State Assembly District and is represented by Democrat Jill Billings. Additionally
column8: Democrat Steve Doyle currently represents suburban La Crosse County in the 94th Assembly District. La Crosse is part of the State Senate District 32 and is represented by Democrat Jennifer Shilling.

column1: Two major regional health care facilities are located in La Crosse: Gundersen Health System and Mayo Clinic Health System - Franciscan Healthcare.

Gundersen Health System is a nationally ranked health care system located in La Crosse that is also an ACS nationally certified Level II Trauma Center. It is the primary hospital associated with the Gundersen Clinic medical group and the location of the Western campus for the University of Wisconsin Medical School.
